functional programming is declarative instead of imperative (OOP), functional programming puts more focus on what things are than on how to get them, e.g. functional: a house has four walls and a roof, imperative: to make a house you have to pour concrete, then put a roof on top, imperative (OOP) asks how, declarative (functional) asks what

in functional programming when we say that x = 3, we don't mean that x is a variable that could contain other values, but literally that x equals 3, and that it will always equal 3, in OOP it is hard to tell what state the program is in since variables change their values, in functional programming the original data stays intact

separation of data and functions is where functional programming contrasts with OOP, in OOP you access data with object methods, but in functional programming, data is represented in simple arrays and hashes, or JavaScript objects, functions return a modified copy

in OOP if you give direct access to internal data, then users of objects have to take care of integrity, e.g. after changing first name, change initials, in functional programming we don't have to worry about keeping our data private because programmers can't alter the data in unwanted ways because data is immutable anyway

in OOP, data and functions are different kinds of entities, we would never think of passing functions as parameters of other functions or returning functions from a function, in functional programming functions work in isolation to data, all data is passed through arguments, in functional programming you make every function pure--there is no state
no private variables, we can't make changes to any piece of data, but you can redefine contents of arrays, or `numbers.reverse()`, eslint prevents this, it will inform us of accident mutation,
